001package squidpony.squidai;

003import squidpony.ArrayTools;
004import squidpony.Maker;
005import squidpony.squidgrid.Direction;
006import squidpony.squidgrid.LOS;
007import squidpony.squidgrid.Measurement;
008import squidpony.squidgrid.Radius;
009import squidpony.squidmath.Coord;
010import squidpony.squidmath.GWTRNG;
011import squidpony.squidmath.GreasedRegion;
012import squidpony.squidmath.IRNG;
013import squidpony.squidmath.IntVLA;
014import squidpony.squidmath.OrderedMap;
015import squidpony.squidmath.RNG;
016import squidpony.squidmath.StatefulRNG;

018import java.io.Serializable;
019import java.util.ArrayList;
020import java.util.Arrays;
021import java.util.Collection;
022import java.util.Collections;
023import java.util.HashSet;

025/**
026 * A group of pathfinding algorithms that explore in all directions equally, and are commonly used when there is more
027 * than one valid goal, or when you want a gradient floodfill to mark each cell in an area with its distance from a
028 * goal. This type of pathfinding is called a Dijkstra Map because it produces the same type of grid of
029 * distances from the nearest goal as Dijkstra's Pathfinding Algorithm can, but the actual algorithm used here is
030 * simpler than Dijkstra's Algorithm, and is more comparable to an optimized breadth-first search that doesn't consider
031 * edge costs. You can set more than one goal with {@link #setGoal(Coord)} or {@link #setGoals(Iterable)}, unlike A*,
032 * which enables such features as pathfinding for creatures that can attack targets between a specified minimum and
033 * maximum distance, and the standard uses of Dijkstra Maps such as finding ideal paths to run away. All these features
034 * have some cost; when paths are short or unobstructed, A* tends to be faster, though some convoluted map shapes can
035 * slow down A* more than DijkstraMap.
036 * <br>
037 * One unique optimization made possible by Dijkstra Maps is for when only one endpoint of a path can change in some
038 * section of a game, such as when you want to draw a path from the (stationary) player's current cell to the cell the
039 * mouse is over, and the mouse can move quickly. This can be done very efficiently by setting the player as a goal with
040 * {@link #setGoal(Coord)}, scanning the map to find distances with {@link #scan(Collection)}, and then as long as the
041 * player's position is unchanged (and no obstacles are added/moved), you can get the path by calling
042 * {@link #findPathPreScanned(Coord)} and giving it the mouse position as a Coord. If various parts of the path can
043 * change instead of just one (such as other NPCs moving around), then you should set a goal or goals and call
044 * {@link #findPath(int, Collection, Collection, Coord, Coord...)}. The parameters for this are used in various methods
045 * in this class with only slight differences: length is the length of path that can be moved "in one go," so 1 for most
046 * roguelikes and more for most strategy games, impassable used for enemies and solid moving obstacles, onlyPassable can
047 * be null in most roguelikes but in strategy games should contain ally positions that can be moved through as long as
048 * no one stops in them, start is the NPC's starting position, and targets is an array or vararg of Coord that the NPC
049 * should pathfind toward (it could be just one Coord, with or without explicitly putting it in an array, or it could be
050 * more and the NPC will pick the closest).
051 * <br>
052 * As a bit of introduction, <a href="http://www.roguebasin.com/index.php?title=Dijkstra_Maps_Visualized">this article
053 * on RogueBasin</a> can provide some useful information on how these work and how to visualize the information they can
054 * produce, while
055 * <a href="http://www.roguebasin.com/index.php?title=The_Incredible_Power_of_Dijkstra_Maps">the original article that
056 * introduced Dijkstra Maps</a> is an inspiring list of the various features Dijkstra Maps can enable.
057 * <br>
058 * If you can't remember how to spell this, just remember: Does It Just Know Stuff? That's Really Awesome!
059 * Created by Tommy Ettinger on 4/4/2015.
060 */
061public class DijkstraMap implements Serializable {
062    private static final long serialVersionUID = -2456306898212944441L;
063
064    /**
065     * This affects how distance is measured on diagonal directions vs. orthogonal directions. MANHATTAN should form a
066     * diamond shape on a featureless map, while CHEBYSHEV and EUCLIDEAN will form a square. EUCLIDEAN does not affect
067     * the length of paths, though it will change the DijkstraMap's gradientMap to have many non-integer values, and
068     * that in turn will make paths this finds much more realistic and smooth (favoring orthogonal directions unless a
069     * diagonal one is a better option).
070     */
071    public Measurement measurement = Measurement.MANHATTAN;
072
073
074    /**
075     * Stores which parts of the map are accessible and which are not. Should not be changed unless the actual physical
076     * terrain has changed. You should call initialize() with a new map instead of changing this directly.
077     */
078    public double[][] physicalMap;
079    /**
080     * The frequently-changing values that are often the point of using this class; goals will have a value of 0, and
081     * any cells that can have a character reach a goal in n steps will have a value of n. Cells that cannot be
082     * entered because they are solid will have a very high value equal to the WALL constant in this class, and cells
083     * that cannot be entered because they cannot reach a goal will have a different very high value equal to the
084     * DARK constant in this class.
085     */
086    public double[][] gradientMap;
087    /**
088     * This stores the entry cost multipliers for each cell; that is, a value of 1.0 is a normal, unmodified cell, but
089     * a value of 0.5 can be entered easily (two cells of its cost can be entered for the cost of one 1.0 cell), and a
090     * value of 2.0 can only be entered with difficulty (one cell of its cost can be entered for the cost of two 1.0
091     * cells). Unlike the measurement field, this does affect the length of paths, as well as the numbers assigned
092     * to gradientMap during a scan. The values for walls are identical to the value used by gradientMap, that is, this
093     * class' WALL static final field. Floors, however, are never given FLOOR as a value, and default to 1.0 .
094     */
095    public double[][] costMap;
096
097    public boolean standardCosts = true;
098    /**
099     * Height of the map. Exciting stuff. Don't change this, instead call initialize().
100     */
101    public int height;
102    /**
103     * Width of the map. Exciting stuff. Don't change this, instead call initialize().
104     */
105    public int width;
106    /**
107     * The latest path that was obtained by calling findPath(). It will not contain the value passed as a starting
108     * cell; only steps that require movement will be included, and so if the path has not been found or a valid
109     * path toward a goal is impossible, this ArrayList will be empty.
110     */
111    public ArrayList<Coord> path;
112
113    private HashSet<Coord> impassable2, friends, tempSet;
114    
115    public boolean cutShort;
116
117    /**
118     * Goals are always marked with 0.
119     */
120    public static final double GOAL = 0.0;
121    /**
122     * Floor cells, which include any walkable cell, are marked with a high number equal to 999200.0 .
123     */
124    public static final double FLOOR = 999200.0;
125    /**
126     * Walls, which are solid no-entry cells, are marked with a high number equal to 999500.0 .
127     */
128    public static final double WALL = 999500.0;
129    /**
130     * This is used to mark cells that the scan couldn't reach, and these dark cells are marked with a high number
131     * equal to 999800.0 .
132     */
133    public static final double DARK = 999800.0;
134    /**
135     * Goals that pathfinding will seek out. The Double value should almost always be 0.0 , the same as the static GOAL
136     * constant in this class.
137     */
138    protected IntVLA goals = new IntVLA(256), fresh = new IntVLA(256);
139
140    /**
141     * The IRNG used to decide which one of multiple equally-short paths to take. You may want to give this a
142     * {@link GWTRNG} if you may target web browsers with GWT, or a {@link RNG} or {@link StatefulRNG} otherwise.
143     */
144    public IRNG rng;
145    private int frustration;
146    public Coord[][] targetMap;
147
148    private Direction[] dirs = new Direction[9];
149
150    private boolean initialized;
151
152    private int mappedCount;
153
154    private int blockingRequirement = 2;
155
156    /**
157     * Construct a DijkstraMap without a level to actually scan. If you use this constructor, you must call an
158     * initialize() method before using this class.
159     */
160    public DijkstraMap() {
161        rng = new GWTRNG();
162        path = new ArrayList<>();
163    }
164
165    /**
166     * Construct a DijkstraMap without a level to actually scan. This constructor allows you to specify an IRNG, such as
167     * an {@link RNG}, before it is ever used in this class. If you use this constructor, you must call an initialize()
168     * method before using any other methods in the class.
169     */
170    public DijkstraMap(IRNG random) {
171        rng = random;
172        path = new ArrayList<>();
173    }
174
175    /**
176     * Used to construct a DijkstraMap from the output of another.
177     *
178     * @param level
179     */
180    public DijkstraMap(final double[][] level) {
181        this(level, Measurement.MANHATTAN);
182    }
183
184    /**
185     * Used to construct a DijkstraMap from the output of another, specifying a distance calculation.
186     *
187     * @param level
188     * @param measurement
189     */
190    public DijkstraMap(final double[][] level, Measurement measurement) {
191        rng = new GWTRNG();
192        this.measurement = measurement;
193        path = new ArrayList<>();
194        initialize(level);
195    }
196
197    /**
198     * Constructor meant to take a char[][] returned by DungeonBoneGen.generate(), or any other
199     * char[][] where '#' means a wall and anything else is a walkable tile. If you only have
200     * a map that uses box-drawing characters, use DungeonUtility.linesToHashes() to get a
201     * map that can be used here.
202     *
203     * @param level
204     */
205    public DijkstraMap(final char[][] level) {
206        this(level, Measurement.MANHATTAN, new GWTRNG());
207    }
208
209    /**
210     * Constructor meant to take a char[][] returned by DungeonBoneGen.generate(), or any other
211     * char[][] where '#' means a wall and anything else is a walkable tile. If you only have
212     * a map that uses box-drawing characters, use DungeonUtility.linesToHashes() to get a
213     * map that can be used here. Also takes an IRNG, such as an {@link RNG}, that ensures
214     * predictable path choices given otherwise identical inputs and circumstances.
215     *
216     * @param level
217     * @param rng   The RNG to use for certain decisions; only affects find* methods like findPath, not scan.
218     */
219    public DijkstraMap(final char[][] level, IRNG rng) {
220        this(level, Measurement.MANHATTAN, rng);
221    }
222
223    /**
224     * Constructor meant to take a char[][] returned by DungeonBoneGen.generate(), or any other
225     * char[][] where one char means a wall and anything else is a walkable tile. If you only have
226     * a map that uses box-drawing characters, use DungeonUtility.linesToHashes() to get a
227     * map that can be used here. You can specify the character used for walls.
228     *
229     * @param level
230     */
231    public DijkstraMap(final char[][] level, char alternateWall) {
232        rng = new GWTRNG();
233        path = new ArrayList<>();
234
235        initialize(level, alternateWall);
236    }
237
238    /**
239     * Constructor meant to take a char[][] returned by DungeonBoneGen.generate(), or any other
240     * char[][] where '#' means a wall and anything else is a walkable tile. If you only have
241     * a map that uses box-drawing characters, use DungeonUtility.linesToHashes() to get a
242     * map that can be used here. This constructor specifies a distance measurement.
243     *
244     * @param level
245     * @param measurement
246     */
247    public DijkstraMap(final char[][] level, Measurement measurement) {
248        this(level, measurement, new GWTRNG());
249    }
250
251    /**
252     * Constructor meant to take a char[][] returned by DungeonBoneGen.generate(), or any other
253     * char[][] where '#' means a wall and anything else is a walkable tile. If you only have
254     * a map that uses box-drawing characters, use DungeonUtility.linesToHashes() to get a
255     * map that can be used here. Also takes a distance measurement and an RNG that ensures
256     * predictable path choices given otherwise identical inputs and circumstances.
257     *
258     * @param level
259     * @param rng   The RNG to use for certain decisions; only affects find* methods like findPath, not scan.
260     */
261    public DijkstraMap(final char[][] level, Measurement measurement, IRNG rng) {
262        this.rng = rng;
263        path = new ArrayList<>();
264        this.measurement = measurement;
265
266        initialize(level);
267    }
268
269    /**
270     * Used to initialize or re-initialize a DijkstraMap that needs a new physicalMap because it either wasn't given
271     * one when it was constructed, or because the contents of the terrain have changed permanently (not if a
272     * creature moved; for that you pass the positions of creatures that block paths to scan() or findPath() ).
273     *
274     * @param level a 2D double array that should be used as the physicalMap for this DijkstraMap
275     * @return this for chaining
276     */
277    public DijkstraMap initialize(final double[][] level) {
278        width = level.length;
279        height = level[0].length;
280        gradientMap = new double[width][height];
281        physicalMap = new double[width][height];
282        costMap = new double[width][height];
283        targetMap = new Coord[width][height];
284        for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
285            System.arraycopy(level[x], 0, gradientMap[x], 0, height);
286            System.arraycopy(level[x], 0, physicalMap[x], 0, height);
287            Arrays.fill(costMap[x], 1.0);
288        }
289        standardCosts = true;
290        impassable2 = new HashSet<>(32, 0.375f);
291        friends = new HashSet<>(32, 0.375f);
292        tempSet = new HashSet<>(32, 0.375f);
293        initialized = true;
294        return this;
295    }
296
297    /**
298     * Used to initialize or re-initialize a DijkstraMap that needs a new physicalMap because it either wasn't given
299     * one when it was constructed, or because the contents of the terrain have changed permanently (not if a
300     * creature moved; for that you pass the positions of creatures that block paths to scan() or findPath() ).
301     *
302     * @param level a 2D char array that this will use to establish which cells are walls ('#' as wall, others as floor)
303     * @return this for chaining
304     */
305    public DijkstraMap initialize(final char[][] level) {
306        width = level.length;
307        height = level[0].length;
308        gradientMap = new double[width][height];
309        physicalMap = new double[width][height];
310        costMap = new double[width][height];
311        targetMap = new Coord[width][height];
312        for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
313            Arrays.fill(costMap[x], 1.0);
314            for (int y = 0; y < height; y++) {
315                double t = (level[x][y] == '#') ? WALL : FLOOR;
316                gradientMap[x][y] = t;
317                physicalMap[x][y] = t;
318            }
319        }
320        standardCosts = true;
321        impassable2 = new HashSet<>(32, 0.375f);
322        friends = new HashSet<>(32, 0.375f);
323        tempSet = new HashSet<>(32, 0.375f);
324        initialized = true;
325        return this;
326    }
327
328    /**
329     * Used to initialize or re-initialize a DijkstraMap that needs a new PhysicalMap because it either wasn't given
330     * one when it was constructed, or because the contents of the terrain have changed permanently (not if a
331     * creature moved; for that you pass the positions of creatures that block paths to scan() or findPath() ). This
332     * initialize() method allows you to specify an alternate wall char other than the default character, '#' .
333     *
334     * @param level a 2D char array that this will use to establish which cells are walls (alternateWall defines the wall char, everything else is floor)
335     * @param alternateWall the char to consider a wall when it appears in level
336     * @return this for chaining
337     */
338    public DijkstraMap initialize(final char[][] level, char alternateWall) {
339        width = level.length;
340        height = level[0].length;
341        gradientMap = new double[width][height];
342        physicalMap = new double[width][height];
343        costMap = new double[width][height];
344        targetMap = new Coord[width][height];
345        for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
346            Arrays.fill(costMap[x], 1.0);
347            for (int y = 0; y < height; y++) {
348                double t = (level[x][y] == alternateWall) ? WALL : FLOOR;
349                gradientMap[x][y] = t;
350                physicalMap[x][y] = t;
351            }
352        }
353        standardCosts = true;
354        impassable2 = new HashSet<>(32, 0.375f);
355        friends = new HashSet<>(32, 0.375f);
356        tempSet = new HashSet<>(32, 0.375f);
357        initialized = true;
358        return this;
359    }
360
361    /**
362     * Used to initialize the entry cost modifiers for games that require variable costs to enter squares. This expects
363     * a char[][] of the same exact dimensions as the 2D array that was used to previously initialize() this
364     * DijkstraMap, treating the '#' char as a wall (impassable) and anything else as having a normal cost to enter.
365     * The costs can be accessed later by using costMap directly (which will have a valid value when this does not
366     * throw an exception), or by calling setCost().
367     *
368     * @param level a 2D char array that uses '#' for walls
369     * @return this DijkstraMap for chaining.
370     */
371    public DijkstraMap initializeCost(final char[][] level) {
372        if (!initialized) throw new IllegalStateException("DijkstraMap must be initialized first!");
373        ArrayTools.fill(costMap, 1.0);
374        standardCosts = true;
375        return this;
376    }
377
378    /**
379     * Used to initialize the entry cost modifiers for games that require variable costs to enter squares. This expects
380     * a char[][] of the same exact dimensions as the 2D array that was used to previously initialize() this
381     * DijkstraMap, treating the '#' char as a wall (impassable) and anything else as having a normal cost to enter.
382     * The costs can be accessed later by using costMap directly (which will have a valid value when this does not
383     * throw an exception), or by calling setCost().
384     * <p/>
385     * This method allows you to specify an alternate wall char other than the default character, '#' .
386     *
387     * @param level         a 2D char array that uses alternateChar for walls.
388     * @param alternateWall a char to use to represent walls.
389     * @return this DijkstraMap for chaining.
390     */
391    public DijkstraMap initializeCost(final char[][] level, char alternateWall) {
392        if (!initialized) throw new IllegalStateException("DijkstraMap must be initialized first!");
393        ArrayTools.fill(costMap, 1.0);
394        standardCosts = true;
395        return this;
396    }
397
398    /**
399     * Used to initialize the entry cost modifiers for games that require variable costs to enter squares. This expects
400     * a double[][] of the same exact dimensions as the 2D array that was used to previously initialize() this
401     * DijkstraMap, using the exact values given in costs as the values to enter cells, even if they aren't what this
402     * class would assign normally -- walls and other impassable values should be given WALL as a value, however.
403     * The costs can be accessed later by using costMap directly (which will have a valid value when this does not
404     * throw an exception), or by calling setCost(). Causes findPath() to always explore the full map instead of
405     * stopping as soon as it finds any path, since unequal costs could make some paths cost less but be discovered
406     * later in the pathfinding process.
407     * <p/>
408     * This method should be slightly more efficient than the other initializeCost methods.
409     *
410     * @param costs a 2D double array that already has the desired cost values
411     * @return this DijkstraMap for chaining.
412     */
413    public DijkstraMap initializeCost(final double[][] costs) {
414        if (!initialized) throw new IllegalStateException("DijkstraMap must be initialized first!");
415        costMap = new double[width][height];
416        for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
417            System.arraycopy(costs[x], 0, costMap[x], 0, height);
418        }
419        standardCosts = false;
420        return this;
421    }
422
423    /**
424     * Internally, DijkstraMap uses int primitives instead of Coord objects, but the specific encoding depends on
425     * this DijkstraMap's width and height. This method converts from a Coord to an encoded int that stores the same
426     * information, but is specific to this width and height and is somewhat more efficient to work with.
427     * @param point a Coord to find an encoded int for
428     * @return an int that encodes the given Coord for this DijkstraMap's width and height
429     */
430    public int encode(final Coord point)
431    {
432        return width * point.y + point.x;
433    }
434    /**
435     * Internally, DijkstraMap uses int primitives instead of Coord objects, but the specific encoding depends on
436     * this DijkstraMap's width and height. This method converts from an x,y point to an encoded int that stores the
437     * same information, but is specific to this width and height and is somewhat more efficient to work with.
438     * @param x the x component of the point to find an encoded int for
439     * @param y the y component of the point to find an encoded int for
440     * @return an int that encodes the given x,y point for this DijkstraMap's width and height
441     */
442    public int encode(final int x, final int y)
443    {
444        return width * y + x;
445    }
446
447    /**
448     * If you for some reason have one of the internally-used ints produced by {@link #encode(Coord)}, this will convert
449     * it back to a Coord if you need it as such. You may prefer using {@link #decodeX(int)} and  {@link #decodeY(int)}
450     * to get the x and y components independently and without involving objects.
451     * @param encoded an encoded int specific to this DijkstraMap's height and width; see {@link #encode(Coord)}
452     * @return the Coord that represents the same x,y position that the given encoded int stores
453     */
454    public Coord decode(final int encoded)
455    {
456        return Coord.get(encoded % width, encoded / width);
457    }
458
459    /**
460     * If you for some reason have one of the internally-used ints produced by {@link #encode(Coord)}, this will decode
461     * the x component of the point encoded in that int. This is an extremely simple method that is equivalent to the
462     * code {@code encoded % width}, where width is a public field in this class. You probably would use this method in
463     * conjunction with {@link #decodeY(int)}, or would instead use {@link #decode(int)} to get a Coord.
464     * @param encoded an encoded int specific to this DijkstraMap's height and width; see {@link #encode(Coord)}
465     * @return the x component of the position that the given encoded int stores
466     */
467    public int decodeX(final int encoded)
468    {
469        return encoded % width;
470    }
471
472    /**
473     * If you for some reason have one of the internally-used ints produced by {@link #encode(Coord)}, this will decode
474     * the y component of the point encoded in that int. This is an extremely simple method that is equivalent to the
475     * code {@code encoded / width}, where width is a public field in this class. You probably would use this method in
476     * conjunction with {@link #decodeX(int)}, or would instead use {@link #decode(int)} to get a Coord.
477     * @param encoded an encoded int specific to this DijkstraMap's height and width; see {@link #encode(Coord)}
478     * @return the y component of the position that the given encoded int stores
479     */
480    public int decodeY(final int encoded)
481    {
482        return encoded / width;
483    }
484
485    /**
486     * Gets the appropriate Measurement to pass to a constructor if you already have a Radius.
487     * Matches SQUARE or CUBE to CHEBYSHEV, DIAMOND or OCTAHEDRON to MANHATTAN, and CIRCLE or SPHERE to EUCLIDEAN.
488     *
489     * @param radius the Radius to find the corresponding Measurement for
490     * @return a Measurement that matches radius; SQUARE to CHEBYSHEV, DIAMOND to MANHATTAN, etc.
491     */
492    public static Measurement findMeasurement(Radius radius) {
493        switch (radius)
494        {
495            case CUBE:
496            case SQUARE:
497                return Measurement.CHEBYSHEV;
498            case DIAMOND:
499            case OCTAHEDRON:
500                return Measurement.MANHATTAN;
501            default:
502                return Measurement.EUCLIDEAN;
503        }
504    }
505
506    /**
507     * Gets the appropriate Radius corresponding to a Measurement.
508     * Matches CHEBYSHEV to SQUARE, MANHATTAN to DIAMOND, and EUCLIDEAN to CIRCLE.
509     * <br>
510     * See also {@link Measurement#matchingRadius()} as a method on Measurement.
511     * @param measurement the Measurement to find the corresponding Radius for
512     * @return a Radius that matches measurement; CHEBYSHEV to SQUARE, MANHATTAN to DIAMOND, etc.
513     */
514    public static Radius findRadius(Measurement measurement) {
515        switch (measurement) {
516            case CHEBYSHEV:
517                return Radius.SQUARE;
518            case EUCLIDEAN:
519                return Radius.CIRCLE;
520            default:
521                return Radius.DIAMOND;
522        }
523    }
524
525    /**
526     * Resets the gradientMap to its original value from physicalMap.
527     */
528    public void resetMap() {
529        if (!initialized) return;
530        for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
531            System.arraycopy(physicalMap[x], 0, gradientMap[x], 0, height);
532        }
533    }
534
535    /**
536     * Resets the targetMap (which is only assigned in the first place if you use findTechniquePath() ).
537     */
538    public void resetTargetMap() {
539        if (!initialized) return;
540        for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
541            for (int y = 0; y < height; y++) {
542                targetMap[x][y] = null;
543            }
544        }
545    }
546
547
548    /**
549     * Resets this DijkstraMap to a state with no goals, no discovered path, and no changes made to gradientMap
550     * relative to physicalMap.
551     */
552    public void reset() {
553        resetMap();
554        resetTargetMap();
555        goals.clear();
556        path.clear();
557        fresh.clear();
558        frustration = 0;
559    }
560
561    /**
562     * Marks a cell as a goal for pathfinding, unless the cell is a wall or unreachable area (then it does nothing).
563     *
564     * @param x
565     * @param y
566     */
567    public void setGoal(int x, int y) {
568        if (!initialized || x < 0 || x >= width || y < 0 || y >= height) return;
569        if (physicalMap[x][y] > FLOOR) {
570            return;
571        }
572
573        goals.add(encode(x, y));
574        gradientMap[x][y] = 0.0;
575    }
576
577    /**
578     * Marks a cell as a goal for pathfinding, unless the cell is a wall or unreachable area (then it does nothing).
579     *
580     * @param pt
581     */
582    public void setGoal(Coord pt) {
583        if (!initialized || !pt.isWithin(width, height)) return;
584        if (physicalMap[pt.x][pt.y] > FLOOR) {
585            return;
586        }
587
588        goals.add(encode(pt));
589        gradientMap[pt.x][pt.y] = 0.0;
590
591    }
592    /**
593     * Marks many cells as goals for pathfinding, ignoring cells in walls or unreachable areas. Possibly more efficient
594     * than a loop that calls {@link #setGoal(Coord)} over and over, since this doesn't need to do a bounds check. The
595     * GreasedRegion passed to this should have the same (or smaller) width and height as this DijkstraMap.
596     *
597     * @param pts a GreasedRegion containing "on" cells to treat as goals; should have the same width and height as this
598     */
599    public void setGoals(GreasedRegion pts) {
600        if (!initialized || pts.width > width || pts.height > height) return;
601        for(Coord c : pts)
602        {
603            if(physicalMap[c.x][c.y] <= FLOOR) {
604                goals.add(encode(c));
605                gradientMap[c.x][c.y] = 0.0;
606            }
607        }
608    }
609
610    /**
611     * Marks many cells as goals for pathfinding, ignoring cells in walls or unreachable areas. Simply loops through
612     * pts and calls {@link #setGoal(Coord)} on each Coord in pts.
613     * If you have a GreasedRegion, you should use it with {@link #setGoals(GreasedRegion)}, which is faster.
614     * @param pts any Iterable of Coord, which can be a List, Set, Queue, etc. of Coords to mark as goals
615     */
616    public void setGoals(Iterable<Coord> pts) {
617        if (!initialized) return;
618        for(Coord c : pts)
619        {
620            setGoal(c);
621        }
622    }
623    /**
624     * Marks many cells as goals for pathfinding, ignoring cells in walls or unreachable areas. Simply loops through
625     * pts and calls {@link #setGoal(Coord)} on each Coord in pts.
626     * @param pts an array of Coord to mark as goals
627     */
628    public void setGoals(Coord[] pts) {
629        if (!initialized) return;
630        for(int i = 0; i < pts.length; i++)
631        {
632            setGoal(pts[i]);
633        }
634    }
635
636    /**
637     * Marks a cell's cost for pathfinding as cost, unless the cell is a wall or unreachable area (then it always sets
638     * the cost to the value of the WALL field).
639     *
640     * @param pt
641     * @param cost
642     */
643    public void setCost(Coord pt, double cost) {
644        if (!initialized || !pt.isWithin(width, height)) return;
645        if (physicalMap[pt.x][pt.y] > FLOOR) {
646            costMap[pt.x][pt.y] = 1.0;
647            return;
648        }
649        if(cost != 1.0)
650            standardCosts = false;
651        costMap[pt.x][pt.y] = cost;
652    }
653
654    /**
655     * Marks a cell's cost for pathfinding as cost, unless the cell is a wall or unreachable area (then it always sets
656     * the cost to the value of the WALL field).
657     *
658     * @param x
659     * @param y
660     * @param cost
661     */
662    public void setCost(int x, int y, double cost) {
663        if (!initialized || x < 0 || x >= width || y < 0 || y >= height) return;
664        if (physicalMap[x][y] > FLOOR) {
665            costMap[x][y] = 1.0;
666            return;
667        }
668        if(cost != 1.0)
669            standardCosts = false;
670        costMap[x][y] = cost;
671    }
672
673    /**
674     * Marks a specific cell in gradientMap as completely impossible to enter.
675     *
676     * @param x
677     * @param y
678     */
679    public void setOccupied(int x, int y) {
680        if (!initialized || x < 0 || x >= width || y < 0 || y >= height) return;
681        gradientMap[x][y] = WALL;
682    }
683
684    /**
685     * Reverts a cell to the value stored in the original state of the level as known by physicalMap.
686     *
687     * @param x
688     * @param y
689     */
690    public void resetCell(int x, int y) {
691        if (!initialized || x < 0 || x >= width || y < 0 || y >= height) return;
692        gradientMap[x][y] = physicalMap[x][y];
693    }
694
695    /**
696     * Reverts a cell to the value stored in the original state of the level as known by physicalMap.
697     *
698     * @param pt
699     */
700    public void resetCell(Coord pt) {
701        if (!initialized || !pt.isWithin(width, height)) return;
702        gradientMap[pt.x][pt.y] = physicalMap[pt.x][pt.y];
703    }
704
705    /**
706     * Used to remove all goals and undo any changes to gradientMap made by having a goal present.
707     */
708    public void clearGoals() {
709        if (!initialized)
710            return;
711        int sz = goals.size, t;
712        for (int i = 0; i < sz; i++) {
713            resetCell(decodeX(t = goals.pop()), decodeY(t));
714        }
715    }
716
717    private void setFresh(final int x, final int y, double counter) {
718        if (x < 0 || x >= width || y < 0 || y >= height || gradientMap[x][y] < counter)
719            return;
720        gradientMap[x][y] = counter;
721        fresh.add(encode(x, y));
722    }
723
724    private void setFresh(final Coord pt, double counter) {
725        if (!pt.isWithin(width, height) || gradientMap[pt.x][pt.y] < counter)
726            return;
727        gradientMap[pt.x][pt.y] = counter;
728        fresh.add(encode(pt));
729    }
730
731    /**
732     * Recalculate the Dijkstra map and return it. Cells that were marked as goals with setGoal will have
733     * a value of 0, the cells adjacent to goals will have a value of 1, and cells progressively further
734     * from goals will have a value equal to the distance from the nearest goal. The exceptions are walls,
735     * which will have a value defined by the WALL constant in this class, and areas that the scan was
736     * unable to reach, which will have a value defined by the DARK constant in this class (typically,
737     * these areas should not be used to place NPCs or items and should be filled with walls). This uses the
738     * current measurement. The result is stored in the {@link #gradientMap} field and a copy is returned.
739     *
740     * @return A 2D double[width][height] using the width and height of what this knows about the physical map.
741     */
742    public double[][] scan() {
743        return scan(null);
744    }
745
746    /**
747     * Recalculate the Dijkstra map and return it. Cells that were marked as goals with setGoal will have
748     * a value of 0, the cells adjacent to goals will have a value of 1, and cells progressively further
749     * from goals will have a value equal to the distance from the nearest goal. The exceptions are walls,
750     * which will have a value defined by the WALL constant in this class, and areas that the scan was
751     * unable to reach, which will have a value defined by the DARK constant in this class (typically,
752     * these areas should not be used to place NPCs or items and should be filled with walls). This uses the
753     * current measurement. The result is stored in the {@link #gradientMap} field and a copy is returned.
754     *
755     * @param impassable A Collection of Coord keys representing the locations of enemies or other moving obstacles to a
756     *                   path that cannot be moved through; this can be null if there are no such obstacles.
757     * @return A 2D double[width][height] using the width and height of what this knows about the physical map.
758     */
759    public double[][] scan(final Collection<Coord> impassable) {
760        scan(null, impassable);
761        double[][] gradientClone = new double[width][height];
762        for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
763            for (int y = 0; y < height; y++) {
764                if (gradientMap[x][y] == FLOOR) {
765                    gradientMap[x][y] = DARK;
766                }
767            }
768            System.arraycopy(gradientMap[x], 0, gradientClone[x], 0, height);
769        }
770
771        return gradientClone;
772    }
773
774    /**
775     * Recalculate the Dijkstra map and return it. Cells that were marked as goals with setGoal will have
776     * a value of 0, the cells adjacent to goals will have a value of 1, and cells progressively further
777     * from goals will have a value equal to the distance from the nearest goal. The exceptions are walls,
778     * which will have a value defined by the WALL constant in this class, and areas that the scan was
779     * unable to reach, which will have a value defined by the DARK constant in this class (typically,
780     * these areas should not be used to place NPCs or items and should be filled with walls). This uses the
781     * current measurement. The result is stored in the {@link #gradientMap} field, and nothing is returned.
782     * If you want the data returned, you can use {@link #scan(Collection)} (which calls this method with
783     * null for the start parameter, then modifies the gradientMap field and returns a copy), or you can
784     * just retrieve the gradientMap (maybe copying it; {@link squidpony.ArrayTools#copy(double[][])} is a
785     * convenient option for copying a 2D double array). If start is non-null, which is usually used when
786     * finding a single path, then cells that didn't need to be explored (because they were further than the
787     * path needed to go from start to goal) will have the value {@link #FLOOR}. You may wish to assign a
788     * different value to these cells in some cases (especially if start is null, which means any cells that
789     * are still FLOOR could not be reached from any goal), and the overloads of scan that return 2D double
790     * arrays do change FLOOR to {@link #DARK}, which is usually treated similarly to {@link #WALL}.
791     *
792     * @param start a Coord representing the location of the pathfinder; may be null, which has this scan the whole map
793     * @param impassable A Collection of Coord keys representing the locations of enemies or other moving obstacles to a
794     *                   path that cannot be moved through; this can be null if there are no such obstacles.
795     */
796    public void scan(final Coord start, final Collection<Coord> impassable) {
797        scan(start, impassable, false);
798    }
799
800    /**
801     * Recalculate the Dijkstra map and return it. Cells in {@link #gradientMap} that had the lowest value
802     * will be treated as goals if {@code nonZeroOptimum} is true; otherwise, only cells marked as goals with
803     * {@link #setGoal(Coord)} will be considered goals and some overhead will be saved. The cells adjacent
804     * to goals will have a value of 1, and cells progressively further from goals will have a value equal to
805     * the distance from the nearest goal. The exceptions are walls, which will have a value defined by the
806     * {@link #WALL} constant in this class, and areas that the scan was unable to reach, which will have a
807     * value defined by the {@link #DARK} constant in this class (typically, these areas should not be used to
808     * place NPCs or items and should be filled with walls). This uses the current {@link #measurement}. The
809     * result is stored in the {@link #gradientMap} field, and nothing is returned. If you want the data
810     * returned, you can use {@link #scan(Collection)} (which calls this method with null for the start
811     * parameter, then modifies the gradientMap field and returns a copy), or you can
812     * just retrieve the gradientMap (maybe copying it; {@link squidpony.ArrayTools#copy(double[][])} is a
813     * convenient option for copying a 2D double array). If start is non-null, which is usually used when
814     * finding a single path, then cells that didn't need to be explored (because they were further than the
815     * path needed to go from start to goal) will have the value {@link #FLOOR}. You may wish to assign a
816     * different value to these cells in some cases (especially if start is null, which means any cells that
817     * are still FLOOR could not be reached from any goal), and the overloads of scan that return 2D double
818     * arrays do change FLOOR to {@link #DARK}, which is usually treated similarly to {@link #WALL}.
819     *
820     * @param start a Coord representing the location of the pathfinder; may be null, which has this scan the whole map
821     * @param impassable A Collection of Coord keys representing the locations of enemies or other moving obstacles to a
822     *                   path that cannot be moved through; this can be null if there are no such obstacles.
823     * @param nonZeroOptimum if the cell to pathfind toward should have a value of {@link #GOAL} (0.0), this should be
824     *                       false; if it should have a different value or if you don't know, it should be true 
825     */
826    public void scan(final Coord start, final Collection<Coord> impassable, final boolean nonZeroOptimum) {
827
828        if (!initialized) return;
829        if (impassable != null && !impassable.isEmpty()) {
830            for (Coord pt : impassable) {
831                if(pt != null && pt.isWithin(width, height))
832                    gradientMap[pt.x][pt.y] = WALL;
833            }
834        }
835        int dec, adjX, adjY, cen, cenX, cenY;
836        fresh.clear();
837        fresh.addAll(goals);
838        for (int i = 0; i < goals.size; i++) {
839            dec = goals.get(i);
840            gradientMap[decodeX(dec)][decodeY(dec)] = GOAL;
841        }
842        double cs, dist;
843        if(nonZeroOptimum) {
844            double currentLowest = 999000.0;
845            for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
846                for (int y = 0; y < height; y++) {
847                    if (gradientMap[x][y] <= FLOOR) {
848                        if (gradientMap[x][y] < currentLowest) {
849                            currentLowest = gradientMap[x][y];
850                            fresh.clear();
851                            fresh.add(encode(x, y));
852                        } else if (gradientMap[x][y] == currentLowest) {
853                            fresh.add(encode(x, y));
854                        }
855                    }
856                }
857            }
858        }
859        int fsz, numAssigned = fresh.size;
860        mappedCount = goals.size;
861        Direction[] moveDirs = (measurement == Measurement.MANHATTAN) ? Direction.CARDINALS : Direction.OUTWARDS;
862
863        while (numAssigned > 0) {
864            numAssigned = 0;
865            fsz = fresh.size;
866            for (int ci = fsz-1; ci >= 0; ci--) {
867                cen = fresh.removeIndex(ci);
868                cenX = decodeX(cen);
869                cenY = decodeY(cen);
870                dist = gradientMap[cenX][cenY];
871
872                for (int d = 0; d < moveDirs.length; d++) {
873                    adjX = cenX + moveDirs[d].deltaX;
874                    adjY = cenY + moveDirs[d].deltaY;
875                    if (adjX < 0 || adjY < 0 || width <= adjX || height <= adjY)
876                        /* Outside the map */
877                        continue;
878                    if(d >= 4 && blockingRequirement > 0) // diagonal
879                    {
880                        if((gradientMap[adjX][cenY] > FLOOR ? 1 : 0)
881                                + (gradientMap[cenX][adjY] > FLOOR ? 1 : 0)
882                                >= blockingRequirement)
883                        {
884                            continue;
885                        }
886                    }
887                    double h = measurement.heuristic(moveDirs[d]);
888                    cs = dist + h * costMap[adjX][adjY];
889                    if (gradientMap[adjX][adjY] <= FLOOR && cs < gradientMap[adjX][adjY]) {
890                        setFresh(adjX, adjY, cs);
891                        ++numAssigned;
892                        ++mappedCount;
893                        if(start != null && start.x == adjX && start.y == adjY && standardCosts)
894                        {
895                            if (impassable != null && !impassable.isEmpty()) {
896                                for (Coord pt : impassable) {
897                                    if(pt != null && pt.isWithin(width, height))
898                                        gradientMap[pt.x][pt.y] = physicalMap[pt.x][pt.y];
899                                }
900                            }
901                            return;
902                        }
903                    }
904                }
905            }
906        }
907        if (impassable != null && !impassable.isEmpty()) {
908            for (Coord pt : impassable) {
909                if(pt != null && pt.isWithin(width, height))
910                    gradientMap[pt.x][pt.y] = physicalMap[pt.x][pt.y];
911            }
912        }
913    }
914
915    /**
916     * Recalculate the Dijkstra map up to a limit and return it. Cells that were marked as goals with setGoal will have
917     * a value of 0, the cells adjacent to goals will have a value of 1, and cells progressively further
918     * from goals will have a value equal to the distance from the nearest goal. If a cell would take more steps to
919     * reach than the given limit, it will have a value of DARK if it was passable instead of the distance. The
920     * exceptions are walls, which will have a value defined by the WALL constant in this class, and areas that the scan
921     * was unable to reach, which will have a value defined by the DARK constant in this class. This uses the
922     * current measurement. The result is stored in the {@link #gradientMap} field and a copy is returned.
923     *
924     * @param limit      The maximum number of steps to scan outward from a goal.
925     * @return A 2D double[width][height] using the width and height of what this knows about the physical map.
926     */
927    public double[][] partialScan(final int limit) {
928        return partialScan(limit, null);
929    }
930
931    /**
932     * Recalculate the Dijkstra map up to a limit and return it. Cells that were marked as goals with setGoal will have
933     * a value of 0, the cells adjacent to goals will have a value of 1, and cells progressively further
934     * from goals will have a value equal to the distance from the nearest goal. If a cell would take more steps to
935     * reach than the given limit, it will have a value of DARK if it was passable instead of the distance. The
936     * exceptions are walls, which will have a value defined by the WALL constant in this class, and areas that the scan
937     * was unable to reach, which will have a value defined by the DARK constant in this class. This uses the
938     * current measurement. The result is stored in the {@link #gradientMap} field and a copy is returned.
939     *
940     * @param limit      The maximum number of steps to scan outward from a goal.
941     * @param impassable A Collection of Coord keys representing the locations of enemies or other moving obstacles to a
942     *                   path that cannot be moved through; this can be null if there are no such obstacles.
943     * @return A 2D double[width][height] using the width and height of what this knows about the physical map.
944     */
945    public double[][] partialScan(final int limit, final Collection<Coord> impassable) {
946        partialScan(null, limit, impassable);
947        double[][] gradientClone = new double[width][height];
948        for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
949            for (int y = 0; y < height; y++) {
950                if (gradientMap[x][y] == FLOOR) {
951                    gradientMap[x][y] = DARK;
952                }
953            }
954            System.arraycopy(gradientMap[x], 0, gradientClone[x], 0, height);
955        }
956
957        return gradientClone;
958    }
959
960    /**
961     * Recalculate the Dijkstra map up to a limit and return it. Cells that were marked as goals with setGoal will have
962     * a value of 0, the cells adjacent to goals will have a value of 1, and cells progressively further
963     * from goals will have a value equal to the distance from the nearest goal. If a cell would take more steps to
964     * reach than the given limit, or if it was otherwise unreachable, it will have a value of {@link #FLOOR} or greater
965     * if it was passable instead of the distance. The exceptions are walls, which will have a value defined by the
966     * {@link #WALL} constant in this class. This uses the current {@link #measurement}. The result is stored in the
967     * {@link #gradientMap} field, and nothing is returned.If you want the data returned, you can use
968     * {@link #partialScan(int, Collection)} (which calls this method with null for the start parameter, then modifies
969     * the gradientMap field and returns a copy), or you can just retrieve the gradientMap (maybe copying it;
970     * {@link squidpony.ArrayTools#copy(double[][])} is a convenient option for copying a 2D double array).
971     * <br>
972     * If start is non-null, which is usually used when finding a single path, then cells that didn't need to be
973     * explored (because they were further than the path needed to go from start to goal) will have the value
974     * {@link #FLOOR}. You may wish to assign a different value to these cells in some cases (especially if start is
975     * null, which means any cells that are still FLOOR could not be reached from any goal), and the overloads of
976     * partialScan that return 2D double arrays do change FLOOR to {@link #DARK}, which is usually treated similarly to
977     * {@link #WALL}.
978     *
979     * @param start a Coord representing the location of the pathfinder; may be null to have this scan more of the map
980     * @param limit      The maximum number of steps to scan outward from a goal.
981     * @param impassable A Collection of Coord keys representing the locations of enemies or other moving obstacles to a
982     *                   path that cannot be moved through; this can be null if there are no such obstacles.
983     */
984    public void partialScan(final Coord start, final int limit, final Collection<Coord> impassable) {
985        partialScan(start, limit, impassable, false);
986    }
987
988    /**
989     * Recalculate the Dijkstra map up to a limit and return it. Cells in {@link #gradientMap} that had the lowest value
990     * will be treated as goals if {@code nonZeroOptimum} is true; otherwise, only cells marked as goals with
991     * {@link #setGoal(Coord)} will be considered goals and some overhead will be saved. If a cell would take more steps
992     * to reach than the given limit, or if it was otherwise unreachable, it will have a value of {@link #FLOOR} or
993     * greater if it was passable instead of the distance. The exceptions are walls, which will have a value defined by
994     * the {@link #WALL} constant in this class. This uses the current {@link #measurement}. The result is stored in the
995     * {@link #gradientMap} field, and nothing is returned.If you want the data returned, you can use
996     * {@link #partialScan(int, Collection)} (which calls this method with null for the start parameter, then modifies
997     * the gradientMap field and returns a copy), or you can just retrieve the gradientMap (maybe copying it;
998     * {@link squidpony.ArrayTools#copy(double[][])} is a convenient option for copying a 2D double array).
999     * <br>
1000     * If start is non-null, which is usually used when finding a single path, then cells that didn't need to be
1001     * explored (because they were further than the path needed to go from start to goal) will have the value
1002     * {@link #FLOOR}. You may wish to assign a different value to these cells in some cases (especially if start is
1003     * null, which means any cells that are still FLOOR could not be reached from any goal), and the overloads of
1004     * partialScan that return 2D double arrays do change FLOOR to {@link #DARK}, which is usually treated similarly to
1005     * {@link #WALL}.
1006     *
1007     * @param start a Coord representing the location of the pathfinder; may be null to have this scan more of the map
1008     * @param limit      The maximum number of steps to scan outward from a goal.
1009     * @param impassable A Collection of Coord keys representing the locations of enemies or other moving obstacles to a
1010     *                   path that cannot be moved through; this can be null if there are no such obstacles.
1011     * @param nonZeroOptimum if the cell to pathfind toward should have a value of {@link #GOAL} (0.0), this should be
1012     *                       false; if it should have a different value or if you don't know, it should be true
1013     */
1014    public void partialScan(final Coord start, final int limit, final Collection<Coord> impassable, final boolean nonZeroOptimum) {
1015
1016        if (!initialized || limit <= 0) return;
1017        if (impassable != null && !impassable.isEmpty()) {
1018            for (Coord pt : impassable) {
1019                if(pt != null && pt.isWithin(width, height))
1020                    gradientMap[pt.x][pt.y] = WALL;
1021            }
1022        }
1023        int dec, adjX, adjY, cen, cenX, cenY;
1024        fresh.clear();
1025        fresh.addAll(goals);
1026        for (int i = 0; i < goals.size; i++) {
1027            //if (closed.containsKey(entry.getIntKey()))
1028            //    continue;
1029            //    closed.remove(entry.getIntKey());
1030            dec = goals.get(i);
1031            gradientMap[decodeX(dec)][decodeY(dec)] = GOAL;
1032        }
1033        double cs, dist;
1034        if(nonZeroOptimum) {
1035            double currentLowest = 999000;
1036            if (start == null) {
1037                for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
1038                    for (int y = 0; y < height; y++) {
1039                        if (gradientMap[x][y] <= FLOOR) {
1040                            if (gradientMap[x][y] < currentLowest) {
1041                                currentLowest = gradientMap[x][y];
1042                                fresh.clear();
1043                                fresh.add(encode(x, y));
1044                            } else if (gradientMap[x][y] == currentLowest) {
1045                                fresh.add(encode(x, y));
1046                            }
1047                        }
1048                    }
1049                }
1050            } else {
1051                final int x0 = Math.max(0, start.x - limit), x1 = Math.min(start.x + limit + 1, width),
1052                        y0 = Math.max(0, start.y - limit), y1 = Math.min(start.y + limit + 1, height);
1053                for (int x = x0; x < x1; x++) {
1054                    for (int y = y0; y < y1; y++) {
1055                        if (gradientMap[x][y] <= FLOOR) {
1056                            if (gradientMap[x][y] < currentLowest) {
1057                                currentLowest = gradientMap[x][y];
1058                                fresh.clear();
1059                                fresh.add(encode(x, y));
1060                            } else if (gradientMap[x][y] == currentLowest) {
1061                                fresh.add(encode(x, y));
1062                            }
1063                        }
1064                    }
1065                }
1066            }
1067        }
1068        int fsz, numAssigned = fresh.size;
1069        mappedCount = goals.size;
1070        Direction[] moveDirs = (measurement == Measurement.MANHATTAN) ? Direction.CARDINALS : Direction.OUTWARDS;
1071
1072        int iter = 0;
1073        while (numAssigned > 0 && iter++ < limit) {
1074            numAssigned = 0;
1075            fsz = fresh.size;
1076            for (int ci = fsz-1; ci >= 0; ci--) {
1077                cen = fresh.removeIndex(ci);
1078                cenX = decodeX(cen);
1079                cenY = decodeY(cen);
1080                dist = gradientMap[cenX][cenY];
1081
1082                for (int d = 0; d < moveDirs.length; d++) {
1083                    adjX = cenX + moveDirs[d].deltaX;
1084                    adjY = cenY + moveDirs[d].deltaY;
1085                    if (adjX < 0 || adjY < 0 || width <= adjX || height <= adjY)
1086                        /* Outside the map */
1087                        continue;
1088                    if(d >= 4 && blockingRequirement > 0) // diagonal
1089                    {
1090                        if((gradientMap[adjX][cenY] > FLOOR ? 1 : 0)
1091                                + (gradientMap[cenX][adjY] > FLOOR ? 1 : 0)
1092                                >= blockingRequirement)
1093                        {
1094                            continue;
1095                        }
1096                    }
1097                    double h = measurement.heuristic(moveDirs[d]);
1098                    cs = dist + h * costMap[adjX][adjY];
1099                    if (gradientMap[adjX][adjY] <= FLOOR && cs < gradientMap[adjX][adjY]) {
1100                        setFresh(adjX, adjY, cs);
1101                        ++numAssigned;
1102                        ++mappedCount;
1103                        if(start != null && start.x == adjX && start.y == adjY && standardCosts)
1104                        {
1105                            if (impassable != null && !impassable.isEmpty()) {
1106                                for (Coord pt : impassable) {
1107                                    if(pt != null && pt.isWithin(width, height))
1108                                        gradientMap[pt.x][pt.y] = physicalMap[pt.x][pt.y];
1109                                }
1110                            }
1111                            return;
1112                        }
1113                    }
1114                }
1115            }
1116        }
1117        if (impassable != null && !impassable.isEmpty()) {
1118            for (Coord pt : impassable) {
1119                if(pt != null && pt.isWithin(width, height))
1120                    gradientMap[pt.x][pt.y] = physicalMap[pt.x][pt.y];
1121            }
1122        }
1123    }
1124
1125    /**
1126     * Recalculate the Dijkstra map until it reaches a Coord in targets, then returns the first target found.
1127     * This uses the current measurement.
1128     *
1129     * @param start   the cell to use as the origin for finding the nearest target
1130     * @param targets the Coords that this is trying to find; it will stop once it finds one
1131     * @return the Coord that it found first.
1132     */
1133    public Coord findNearest(Coord start, Collection<Coord> targets) {
1134        if (!initialized) return null;
1135        if (targets == null)
1136            return null;
1137        if (targets.contains(start))
1138            return start;
1139        resetMap();
1140        Coord start2 = start;
1141        int xShift = width / 6, yShift = height / 6;
1142        while (physicalMap[start.x][start.y] >= WALL && frustration < 50) {
1143            start2 = Coord.get(Math.min(Math.max(1, start.x + rng.nextInt(1 + xShift * 2) - xShift), width - 2),
1144                    Math.min(Math.max(1, start.y + rng.nextInt(1 + yShift * 2) - yShift), height - 2));
1145        }
1146        gradientMap[start2.x][start2.y] = 0.0;
1147        int adjX, adjY, cen, cenX, cenY;
1148        double cs, dist;
1149        Coord adj;
1150        fresh.clear();
1151        fresh.add(encode(start2));
1152        int fsz, numAssigned = 1;
1153        mappedCount = 1;
1154        Direction[] moveDirs = (measurement == Measurement.MANHATTAN) ? Direction.CARDINALS : Direction.OUTWARDS;
1155
1156        while (numAssigned > 0) {
1157            numAssigned = 0;
1158            fsz = fresh.size;
1159            for (int ci = fsz-1; ci >= 0; ci--) {
1160                cen = fresh.removeIndex(ci);
1161                cenX = decodeX(cen);
1162                cenY = decodeY(cen);
1163                dist = gradientMap[cenX][cenY];
1164
1165                for (int d = 0; d < moveDirs.length; d++) {
1166                    adjX = cenX + moveDirs[d].deltaX;
1167                    adjY = cenY + moveDirs[d].deltaY;
1168                    if (adjX < 0 || adjY < 0 || width <= adjX || height <= adjY)
1169                        /* Outside the map */
1170                        continue;
1171                    if(d >= 4 && blockingRequirement > 0) // diagonal
1172                    {
1173                        if((gradientMap[adjX][cenY] > FLOOR ? 1 : 0)
1174                                + (gradientMap[cenX][adjY] > FLOOR ? 1 : 0)
1175                                >= blockingRequirement)
1176                        {
1177                            continue;
1178                        }
1179                    }
1180                    double h = measurement.heuristic(moveDirs[d]);
1181                    cs = dist + h * costMap[adjX][adjY];
1182                    if (gradientMap[adjX][adjY] <= FLOOR && cs < gradientMap[adjX][adjY]) {
1183                        ++mappedCount;
1184                        if (targets.contains(adj = Coord.get(adjX, adjY))) {
1185                            fresh.clear();
1186                            return adj;
1187                        }
1188                        setFresh(adjX, adjY, cs);
1189                        ++numAssigned;
1190                    }
1191                }
1192            }
1193        }
1194
1195        return null;
1196    }
1197
1198    /**
1199     * Recalculate the Dijkstra map until it reaches a Coord in targets, then returns the first target found.
1200     * This uses the current measurement.
1201     *
1202     * @param start   the cell to use as the origin for finding the nearest target
1203     * @param targets the Coords that this is trying to find; it will stop once it finds one
1204     * @return the Coord that it found first.
1205     */
1206    public Coord findNearest(Coord start, Coord... targets) {
1207        return findNearest(start, Maker.makeHS(targets));
1208    }
1209
1210    /**
1211     * If you have a target or group of targets you want to pathfind to without scanning the full map, this can be good.
1212     * It may find sub-optimal paths in the presence of costs to move into cells. It is useful when you want to move in
1213     * a straight line to a known nearby goal.
1214     *
1215     * @param start   your starting location
1216     * @param targets an array or vararg of Coords to pathfind to the nearest of
1217     * @return an ArrayList of Coord that goes from a cell adjacent to start and goes to one of the targets. Copy of path.
1218     */
1219    public ArrayList<Coord> findShortcutPath(Coord start, Coord... targets) {
1220        if (targets.length == 0) {
1221            cutShort = true;
1222            path.clear();
1223            return new ArrayList<>(path);
1224        }
1225        Coord currentPos = findNearest(start, targets);
1226        while (true) {
1227            if (frustration > 500) {
1228                path.clear();
1229                break;
1230            }
1231            double best = gradientMap[currentPos.x][currentPos.y];
1232            appendDirToShuffle(rng);
1233            int choice = 0;
1234
1235            for (int d = 0; d < measurement.directionCount() + 1; d++) {
1236                Coord pt = Coord.get(currentPos.x + dirs[d].deltaX, currentPos.y + dirs[d].deltaY);
1237                if(!pt.isWithin(width, height))
1238                    continue;
1239                if (gradientMap[pt.x][pt.y] < best) {
1240                    if (dirs[choice] == Direction.NONE || !path.contains(pt)) {
1241                        best = gradientMap[pt.x][pt.y];
1242                        choice = d;
1243                    }
1244                }
1245            }
1246
1247            if (best >= gradientMap[currentPos.x][currentPos.y] || physicalMap[currentPos.x + dirs[choice].deltaX][currentPos.y + dirs[choice].deltaY] > FLOOR) {
1248                cutShort = true;
1249                frustration = 0;
1250                return new ArrayList<>(path);
1251            }
1252            currentPos = currentPos.translate(dirs[choice].deltaX, dirs[choice].deltaY);
1253            if (gradientMap[currentPos.x][currentPos.y] == 0)
1254                break;
1255            path.add(currentPos);
1256            frustration++;
1257        }
1258        frustration = 0;
1259        cutShort = false;
1260        Collections.reverse(path);
1261        return new ArrayList<>(path);
1262
1263    }
1264
1265    /**
1266     * Recalculate the Dijkstra map until it reaches a Coord in targets, then returns the first several targets found,
1267     * up to limit or less if the map is fully searched without finding enough.
1268     * This uses the current measurement.
1269     *
1270     * @param start   the cell to use as the origin for finding the nearest targets
1271     * @param limit   the maximum number of targets to find before returning
1272     * @param targets the Coords that this is trying to find; it will stop once it finds enough (based on limit)
1273     * @return the Coords that it found first.
1274     */
1275    public ArrayList<Coord> findNearestMultiple(Coord start, int limit, Collection<Coord> targets) {
1276        if (!initialized) return null;
1277        ArrayList<Coord> found = new ArrayList<>(limit);
1278        if (targets == null)
1279            return found;
1280        if (targets.contains(start))
1281            return found;
1282        resetMap();
1283        Coord start2 = start;
1284        int xShift = width / 6, yShift = height / 6;
1285        while (physicalMap[start.x][start.y] >= WALL && frustration < 50) {
1286            start2 = Coord.get(Math.min(Math.max(1, start.x + rng.nextInt(1 + xShift * 2) - xShift), width - 2),
1287                    Math.min(Math.max(1, start.y + rng.nextInt(1 + yShift * 2) - yShift), height - 2));
1288        }
1289        gradientMap[start2.x][start2.y] = 0.0;
1290        int adjX, adjY, cen, cenX, cenY;
1291        double cs, dist;
1292        Coord adj;
1293        fresh.clear();
1294        fresh.add(encode(start2));
1295        int fsz, numAssigned = 1;
1296        mappedCount = 1;
1297        Direction[] moveDirs = (measurement == Measurement.MANHATTAN) ? Direction.CARDINALS : Direction.OUTWARDS;
1298
1299        while (numAssigned > 0) {
1300            numAssigned = 0;
1301            fsz = fresh.size;
1302            for (int ci = fsz-1; ci >= 0; ci--) {
1303                cen = fresh.removeIndex(ci);
1304                cenX = decodeX(cen);
1305                cenY = decodeY(cen);
1306                dist = gradientMap[cenX][cenY];
1307
1308                for (int d = 0; d < moveDirs.length; d++) {
1309                    adjX = cenX + moveDirs[d].deltaX;
1310                    adjY = cenY + moveDirs[d].deltaY;
1311                    if (adjX < 0 || adjY < 0 || width <= adjX || height <= adjY)
1312                        /* Outside the map */
1313                        continue;
1314                    if(d >= 4 && blockingRequirement > 0) // diagonal
1315                    {
1316                        if((gradientMap[adjX][cenY] > FLOOR ? 1 : 0)
1317                                + (gradientMap[cenX][adjY] > FLOOR ? 1 : 0)
1318                                >= blockingRequirement)
1319                        {
1320                            continue;
1321                        }
1322                    }
1323                    double h = measurement.heuristic(moveDirs[d]);
1324                    cs = dist + h * costMap[adjX][adjY];
1325                    if (gradientMap[adjX][adjY] <= FLOOR && cs < gradientMap[adjX][adjY]) {
1326                        ++mappedCount;
1327                        if (targets.contains(adj = Coord.get(adjX, adjY))) {
1328                            found.add(adj);
1329                            if (found.size() >= limit) {
1330                                fresh.clear();
1331                                return found;
1332                            }
1333                        }
1334                        setFresh(adjX, adjY, cs);
1335                        ++numAssigned;
1336                    }
1337                }
1338            }
1339        }
1340        return found;
1341    }
1342
1343    /**
1344     * Recalculate the Dijkstra map for a creature that is potentially larger than 1x1 cell and return it. The value of
1345     * a cell in the returned Dijkstra map assumes that a creature is square, with a side length equal to the passed
1346     * size, that its minimum-x, minimum-y cell is the starting cell, and that any cell with a distance number
1347     * represents the distance for the creature's minimum-x, minimum-y cell to reach it. Cells that cannot be entered
1348     * by the minimum-x, minimum-y cell because of sizing (such as a floor cell next to a maximum-x and/or maximum-y
1349     * wall if size is &gt; 1) will be marked as DARK. Cells that were marked as goals with setGoal will have
1350     * a value of 0, the cells adjacent to goals will have a value of 1, and cells progressively further
1351     * from goals will have a value equal to the distance from the nearest goal. The exceptions are walls,
1352     * which will have a value defined by the WALL constant in this class, and areas that the scan was
1353     * unable to reach, which will have a value defined by the DARK constant in this class. (typically,
1354     * these areas should not be used to place NPCs or items and should be filled with walls). This uses the
1355     * current measurement.  The result is stored in the {@link #gradientMap} field and a copy is returned.
1356     *
1357     * @param impassable A Collection of Coord keys representing the locations of enemies or other moving obstacles to a
1358     *                   path that cannot be moved through; this can be null if there are no such obstacles.
1359     * @param size       The length of one side of a square creature using this to find a path, i.e. 2 for a 2x2 cell
1360     *                   creature. Non-square creatures are not supported because turning is really hard.
1361     * @return A 2D double[width][height] using the width and height of what this knows about the physical map.
1362     */
1363    public double[][] scan(final Collection<Coord> impassable, final int size) {
1364        scan(null, impassable, size);
1365        double[][] gradientClone = new double[width][height];
1366        for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
1367            for (int y = 0; y < height; y++) {
1368                if (gradientMap[x][y] == FLOOR) {
1369                    gradientMap[x][y] = DARK;
1370                }
1371            }
1372            System.arraycopy(gradientMap[x], 0, gradientClone[x], 0, height);
1373        }
1374        return gradientClone;
1375
1376    }
1377
1378    /**
1379     * Recalculate the Dijkstra map for a creature that is potentially larger than 1x1 cell and return it. The value of
1380     * a cell in the returned Dijkstra map assumes that a creature is square, with a side length equal to the passed
1381     * size, that its minimum-x, minimum-y cell is the starting cell, and that any cell with a distance number
1382     * represents the distance for the creature's minimum-x, minimum-y cell to reach it. Cells that cannot be entered
1383     * by the minimum-x, minimum-y cell because of sizing (such as a floor cell next to a maximum-x and/or maximum-y
1384     * wall if size is &gt; 1) will be marked as DARK. Cells that were marked as goals with setGoal will have
1385     * a value of 0, the cells adjacent to goals will have a value of 1, and cells progressively further
1386     * from goals will have a value equal to the distance from the nearest goal. The exceptions are walls,
1387     * which will have a value defined by the WALL constant in this class, and areas that the scan was
1388     * unable to reach, which will have a value defined by the DARK constant in this class. (typically,
1389     * these areas should not be used to place NPCs or items and should be filled with walls). This uses the
1390     * current measurement.  The result is stored in the {@link #gradientMap} field, and nothing is returned.
1391     * If you want the data returned, you can use {@link #scan(Collection, int)} (which calls this method with
1392     * null for the start parameter, then modifies the gradientMap field and returns a copy), or you can
1393     * just retrieve the gradientMap (maybe copying it; {@link squidpony.ArrayTools#copy(double[][])} is a
1394     * convenient option for copying a 2D double array). If start is non-null, which is usually used when
1395     * finding a single path, then cells that didn't need to be explored (because they were further than the
1396     * path needed to go from start to goal) will have the value {@link #FLOOR}. You may wish to assign a
1397     * different value to these cells in some cases (especially if start is null, which means any cells that
1398     * are still FLOOR could not be reached from any goal), and the overloads of scan that return 2D double
1399     * arrays do change FLOOR to {@link #DARK}, which is usually treated similarly to {@link #WALL}.
1400     *
1401     * @param impassable A Collection of Coord keys representing the locations of enemies or other moving obstacles to a
1402     *                   path that cannot be moved through; this can be null if there are no such obstacles.
1403     * @param size       The length of one side of a square creature using this to find a path, i.e. 2 for a 2x2 cell
1404     *                   creature. Non-square creatures are not supported because turning is really hard.
1405     */
1406    public void scan(final Coord start, final Collection<Coord> impassable, final int size) {
1407
1408        if (!initialized) return;
1409        double[][] gradientClone = ArrayTools.copy(gradientMap);
1410        if (impassable != null && !impassable.isEmpty()) {
1411            for (Coord pt : impassable) {
1412                if(pt != null && pt.isWithin(width, height))
1413                    gradientMap[pt.x][pt.y] = WALL;
1414            }
1415        }
1416        for (int xx = size; xx < width; xx++) {
1417            for (int yy = size; yy < height; yy++) {
1418                if(gradientMap[xx][yy] > FLOOR) {
1419                    for (int xs = xx, xi = 0; xi < size && xs >= 0; xs--, xi++) {
1420                        for (int ys = yy, yi = 0; yi < size && ys >= 0; ys--, yi++) {
1421                            gradientClone[xs][ys] = WALL;
1422                        }
1423                    }
1424                }
1425            }
1426        }
1427        int dec, adjX, adjY, cen, cenX, cenY;
1428
1429        PER_GOAL:
1430        for (int i = 0; i < goals.size; i++) {
1431            dec = goals.get(i);
1432            for (int xs = decodeX(dec), xi = 0; xi < size && xs >= 0; xs--, xi++) {
1433                for (int ys = decodeY(dec), yi = 0; yi < size && ys >= 0; ys--, yi++) {
1434                    if(physicalMap[xs][ys] > FLOOR)
1435                        continue PER_GOAL;
1436                    gradientClone[xs][ys] = GOAL;
1437                }
1438            }
1439        }
1440        double currentLowest = 999000, cs, dist;
1441        fresh.clear();
1442        for (int x = 0; x < width; x++) {
1443            for (int y = 0; y < height; y++) {
1444                if (gradientClone[x][y] <= FLOOR) {
1445                    if (gradientClone[x][y] < currentLowest) {
1446                        currentLowest = gradientClone[x][y];
1447                        fresh.clear();
1448                        fresh.add(encode(x, y));
1449                    } else if (gradientClone[x][y] == currentLowest) {
1450                        fresh.add(encode(x, y));
1451                    }
1452                }
1453            }
1454        }
1455        int fsz, numAssigned = fresh.size;
1456        mappedCount = goals.size;
1457        Direction[] moveDirs = (measurement == Measurement.MANHATTAN) ? Direction.CARDINALS : Direction.OUTWARDS;
1458
1459        while (numAssigned > 0) {
1460            numAssigned = 0;
1461            fsz = fresh.size;
1462            for (int ci = fsz-1; ci >= 0; ci--) {
1463                cen = fresh.removeIndex(ci);
1464                cenX = decodeX(cen);
1465                cenY = decodeY(cen);
1466                dist = gradientClone[cenX][cenY];
1467
1468                for (int d = 0; d < moveDirs.length; d++) {
1469                    adjX = cenX + moveDirs[d].deltaX;
1470                    adjY = cenY + moveDirs[d].deltaY;
1471                    if (adjX < 0 || adjY < 0 || width <= adjX || height <= adjY)
1472                        /* Outside the map */
1473                        continue;
1474                    if(d >= 4 && blockingRequirement > 0) // diagonal
1475                    {
1476                        if((gradientClone[adjX][cenY] > FLOOR ? 1 : 0)
1477                                + (gradientClone[cenX][adjY] > FLOOR ? 1 : 0)
1478                                >= blockingRequirement)
1479                        {
1480                            continue;
1481                        }
1482                    }
1483                    double h = measurement.heuristic(moveDirs[d]);
1484                    cs = dist + h * costMap[adjX][adjY];
1485                    if (gradientClone[adjX][adjY] <= FLOOR && cs < gradientClone[adjX][adjY]) {
1486                        setFresh(adjX, adjY, cs);
1487                        ++numAssigned;
1488                        ++mappedCount;
1489                        if(start != null && start.x == adjX && start.y == adjY && standardCosts)
1490                        {
1491                            if (impassable != null && !impassable.isEmpty()) {
1492                                for (Coord pt : impassable) {
1493                                    if(pt != null && pt.isWithin(width, height)) {
1494                                        for (int xs = pt.x, xi = 0; xi < size && xs >= 0; xs--, xi++) {
1495                                            for (int ys = pt.y, yi = 0; yi < size && ys >= 0; ys--, yi++) {
1496                                                gradientClone[xs][ys] = physicalMap[xs][ys];
1497                                            }
1498                                        }
1499                                    }
1500                                }
1501                            }
1502                            gradientMap = gradientClone;
1503                            return;
1504                        }
1505                    }
1506                }
1507            }
